required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Enhancing Indoor, Community, and Advanced Wheelchair Skills in Spinal Cord Injury (SCI)
clinical_study.official_title: Enhancing Indoor, Community, and Advanced Wheelchair Skills in SCI

lead_sponsor.agency: VA Office of Research and Development

clinical_study.source: VA Office of Research and Development

brief_summary.textblock: We propose to test an evidence-based wheelchair skills training program to optimize wheelchair safety and performance in veterans with SCI. The proposed training program incorporates emerging evidence on wheelchair biomechanics and motor-skills learning, and addresses recommendations in a new clinical practice guideline. Given the difficulty in translating wheelchair skills learned in a therapy clinic with "real world" problems in the home and community post-discharge, we are proposing to conduct the wheelchair skills training in and around the veteran's home. The immediate goal is to enhance ability, performance time, safety, community participation, and quality of life, while minimizing physical strain. The ultimate goal is to reduce morbidity/mortality associated with wheelchair use and promote successful aging with a disability.

detailed_description.textblock:
The purpose of this 3-year randomized controlled clinical trial is to evaluate use of a community-based wheelchair skills training program (WSTP). Objectives include:
1. Determine the immediate and sustained effects of a WSTP on ability, performance time, and physical strain.
2. Examine the effects of mediating and moderating variables on ability, performance time, and physical strain.
3. Examine the effects of a WSTP on safety, community participation, and quality of life.
4. Promote dissemination of WSTP in VA SCI Centers through two key activities: (a) Design innovative marketing plans to increase participation and promote patient-centeredness based on patient-perceived benefits. (b) Estimate health care resources needed to add home-based

primary_outcome.description: The WST is a standardized evaluation method that permits a set of representative wheelchair skills to be objectively, simply and inexpensively documented. The WST is an instrument for the objective evaluation of wheelchair skills. The WST consists of a series of commonly used wheelchair skills spanning the spectrum from those as basic as applying brakes to those as difficult as climbing curbs and performing wheelies. The WSC encompasses 57 skills (in Version 4.1) which result in a total score. The WST provide a pass-fail score for each skill. Refusal to attempt a skill (e.g. because of fear) constitutes a failing grade. The numerator is the Total Raw Score (i.e., the number of individual skills awarded a passing score) and the denominator is the number of applicable skills (i.e., the total number of skills minus those awarded NP scores). 100% is the maximum possible percentage score.

secondary_outcome.measure: Craig Handicap Assessment and Reporting Technique (CHART): Physical Independence Subscale
secondary_outcome.description: Use as a measure of handicap that captures the interaction of the person and the environment, and of community reintegration and participation. The CHART quantifies handicap by evaluating five domains: physical independence, mobility, occupation, social integration, and economic self-sufficiency. The CHART is made up of 27 questions with responses that are countable or in a yes/no format. Each of the five subscales has a maximum score of 100, and they may be summed to form a total score. High scores indicate lesser handicap. The CHART was developed as a specific instrument to measure handicap, is the only measure of that concept validated specifically for persons with SCI, and is currently the most widely used measure related to community reintegration in SCI. The Physical Independence subscale measures the ability to sustain a customarily effective independent existence.

secondary_outcome.measure: Craig Handicap Assessment and Reporting Technique (CHART): Mobility Subscale
secondary_outcome.description: Use as a measure of handicap that captures the interaction of the person and the environment, and of community reintegration and participation. The CHART quantifies handicap by evaluating five domains: physical independence, mobility, occupation, social integration, and economic self-sufficiency. The CHART is made up of 27 questions with responses that are countable or in a yes/no format. Each of the five subscales has a maximum score of 100, and they may be summed to form a total score. High scores indicate lesser handicap. The CHART was developed as a specific instrument to measure handicap, is the only measure of that concept validated specifically for persons with SCI, and is currently the most widely used measure related to community reintegration in SCI. The Mobility Subscale measures the ability to move about effectively in his/her surroundings.

secondary_outcome.measure: Craig Handicap Assessment and Reporting Technique (CHART): Occupation Subscale
secondary_outcome.description: Use as a measure of handicap that captures the interaction of the person and the environment, and of community reintegration and participation. The CHART quantifies handicap by evaluating five domains: physical independence, mobility, occupation, social integration, and economic self-sufficiency. The CHART is made up of 27 questions with responses that are countable or in a yes/no format. Each of the five subscales has a maximum score of 100, and they may be summed to form a total score. High scores indicate lesser handicap. The CHART was developed as a specific instrument to measure handicap, is the only measure of that concept validated specifically for persons with SCI, and is currently the most widely used measure related to community reintegration in SCI. The Occupation Subscale measures the ability to occupy time in the manner customary to that person's sex, age, and culture.

secondary_outcome.measure: Craig Handicap Assessment and Reporting Technique (CHART): Social Integration Subscale
secondary_outcome.description: Use as a measure of handicap that captures the interaction of the person and the environment, and of community reintegration and participation. The CHART quantifies handicap by evaluating five domains: physical independence, mobility, occupation, social integration, and economic self-sufficiency. The CHART is made up of 27 questions with responses that are countable or in a yes/no format. Each of the five subscales has a maximum score of 100, and they may be summed to form a total score. High scores indicate lesser handicap. The CHART was developed as a specific instrument to measure handicap, is the only measure of that concept validated specifically for persons with SCI, and is currently the most widely used measure related to community reintegration in SCI. The Social Integration Subscale measures the ability to participate in and maintain customary social relationships.

secondary_outcome.measure: Craig Handicap Assessment and Reporting Technique (CHART): Economic Self-Sufficiency Subscale
secondary_outcome.description: Use as a measure of handicap that captures the interaction of the person and the environment, and of community reintegration and participation. The CHART quantifies handicap by evaluating five domains: physical independence, mobility, occupation, social integration, and economic self-sufficiency. The CHART is made up of 27 questions with responses that are countable or in a yes/no format. Each of the five subscales has a maximum score of 100, and they may be summed to form a total score. High scores indicate lesser handicap. The CHART was developed as a specific instrument to measure handicap, is the only measure of that concept validated specifically for persons with SCI, and is currently the most widely used measure related to community reintegration in SCI. The Economic Self-Sufficiency subscale measures the ability to sustain customary socio-economic activity and independence.

arm_group.description: Subjects are provided with five weeks of wheelchair skills training, tailored to meet their needs. The WSP is a set of assessment and training protocols related to wheelchair skills. The WSP includes the Wheelchair Skills Test (WST), the Wheelchair Skills Training Program (WSTP) and related materials.

Basic health educational training sessions: Five sessions are held with subjects to provide them additional information regarding health related issues - such as nutrition, proper hand hygiene, sports, etc.

intervention.description: Subjects are provided with five weeks of wheelchair skills training, tailored to meet their needs.
Five sessions are held with subjects to provide them with educational information regarding health related issues - such as nutrition, proper hand hygiene, sports, etc.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- SCI for at least 1 year (neurologically stable)
- Level of injury: C6 and below who use manual wheelchair as a primary means of mobility
- Able to self-propel wheelchair
- Between the ages of 18-75
- Able to follow simple instructions
Exclusion Criteria:
- Progressive disease (e.g. spinal tumor)
- Extended bedrest for more than 30 days
- Ventilator-dependent
- Any cardiac or respiratory condition that would limit subject's physical performance
- Unstable medical conditions
- Use power wheelchair or scooter as primary means of mobility
- Pregnancy

overall_official.affiliation: James A. Haley Veterans' Hospital, Tampa, FL

facility.name: James A. Haley Veterans' Hospital, Tampa, FL
VA Medical Center, Jamaica Plain Campus

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruitment intervals at each site were as follows: 4/08-8/10 at Tampa, 6/08-8/10 at Boston, and 11/08-10/09 at Augusta. Recruitment efforts included posters in VA elevators and in clinic waiting rooms, study brochures, and/or referral of subject by primary care physicians.

baseline.population: One hundred thirty-eight veterans were recruited and randomly selected for group assignments.

measure.title: Wheelchair Skills Test (WST)
measure.description: The WST is a standardized evaluation method that permits a set of representative wheelchair skills to be objectively, simply and inexpensively documented. The WST is an instrument for the objective evaluation of wheelchair skills. The WST consists of a series of commonly used wheelchair skills spanning the spectrum from those as basic as applying brakes to those as difficult as climbing curbs and performing wheelies. The WSC encompasses 57 skills (in Version 4.1) which result in a total score. The WST provide a pass-fail score for each skill. Refusal to attempt a skill (e.g. because of fear) constitutes a failing grade. The numerator is the Total Raw Score (i.e., the number of individual skills awarded a passing score) and the denominator is the number of applicable skills (i.e., the total number of skills minus those awarded NP scores). 100% is the maximum possible percentage score.

outcome.title: Craig Handicap Assessment and Reporting Technique (CHART): Physical Independence Subscale
outcome.description: Use as a measure of handicap that captures the interaction of the person and the environment, and of community reintegration and participation. The CHART quantifies handicap by evaluating five domains: physical independence, mobility, occupation, social integration, and economic self-sufficiency. The CHART is made up of 27 questions with responses that are countable or in a yes/no format. Each of the five subscales has a maximum score of 100, and they may be summed to form a total score. High scores indicate lesser handicap. The CHART was developed as a specific instrument to measure handicap, is the only measure of that concept validated specifically for persons with SCI, and is currently the most widely used measure related to community reintegration in SCI. The Physical Independence subscale measures the ability to sustain a customarily effective independent existence.

event.sub_title: Total, serious adverse events
Hospitalization due to depression and acute alcohol Intoxication
Hospitalization due to chronic heel/knee ulcers and heavy alcohol consumption
Hospitalization due to fever and possible infection
Hospitalization due to fever and nausea
Hospitalization due to bleeding colostomy and urinary tract infection
Hospitalization due to emesis and dehydration
Hospitalization due to stroke/mental status change
Hospitalization due to fever and urinary tract infection
Hospitalization due to pneumonia and altered mental status
Hospitalization due to mental status change and dehydration
Hospitalized for fever and confusion
Hospitalized for pneumonia, leukocytosis, fever and UTI.
Hospitalized for mental status changes, vomiting blood and dehydration.
Hospitalized for fever, chills, and nephrostomy tube placement for kidney stone/IV anti
Hospitalization due to change in mental status and declining health
Hospitalization due to pneumonia
Hospitalization due to fever and infection
Hospitalization due to infected right foot pressure ulcer
Hospitalization due to wound re-opening
Hospitalization for colonoscopy screening
Hospitalization due to bladder biopsy and cystoscopy
Hospitalization due to infected ankle wound
Hospitalization due to urinary tract infection
Hospitalization due to bladder stone
Hospitalization due to surgical incision re-opening
Hospitalization due to hand surgery.
Total, other adverse events

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
